title: How to Photograph an Overweight Person

steps.headline: Use a longer lens.
steps.description: Either a telephoto lens or a long zoom. This helps to compress the shot and reduces distortion.

steps.headline: Don't shoot from a lower angle.
steps.description: Shoot straight across or at a bit of an upward angle. Shooting from a higher location looking down is a common ploy used by photographers and is considered somewhat overused. However, try it and see if it helps.

steps.headline: If photographing multiple people, use one to shield the view of the other.
Don't shoot the body of the individual.
steps.description: Try headshots and head and shoulders shots.

steps.headline: Work with the lighting.
steps.description: Short (or narrow) lighting works well with rounder faces.

steps.headline: Find a flattering position.
steps.description: Have one shoulder angled away from the camera.

steps.headline: Be sure the subject's face is pointed approximately 45 degrees away from the camera.
steps.description: This way, the main light can light the side that is turned away and a weaker fill light for the other side of the face. You will need to experiment and adjust because it will show more facial contours than broad lighting will and may give a more masculine look.

steps.headline: Be aware of the possibility of a 'double chin' and use lighting and position to alleviate the look of it.

text: Use a longer lens. Either a telephoto lens or a long zoom. This helps to compress the shot and reduces distortion. Don't shoot from a lower angle. Shoot straight across or at a bit of an upward angle. Shooting from a higher location looking down is a common ploy used by photographers and is considered somewhat overused. However, try it and see if it helps. If photographing multiple people, use one to shield the view of the other.  Don't shoot the body of the individual. Try headshots and head and shoulders shots. Work with the lighting. Short (or narrow) lighting works well with rounder faces. Find a flattering position. Have one shoulder angled away from the camera. Be sure the subject's face is pointed approximately 45 degrees away from the camera. This way, the main light can light the side that is turned away and a weaker fill light for the other side of the face. You will need to experiment and adjust because it will show more facial contours than broad lighting will and may give a more masculine look. Be aware of the possibility of a 'double chin' and use lighting and position to alleviate the look of it.
